column3: I don't think it's correct to assume `clang++` exists here, as well as is the compiler that is used to compile qt?
Oh, I misunderstand what this does. It doesn't actually *run* the command but searches for it in expanded `$($(1)_cxx)`.\n\nIt does seem somewhat over-specific to look for `clang++ -stdlib=libc++`.

I think it is not an assumption, rather an option. If `clang++` compiler with `-stdlib=libc++` flag is used to compile the `qt` package, we just choose the correct `linux-clang-libc++` mkspec.\n\nOtherwise, the `linux-g++-64` mkspec is used as usually.
> It does seem somewhat over-specific to look for `clang++ -stdlib=libc++`.\n\nTrue. Because `clang++ -stdlib=libc++` requires the `linux-clang-libc++` mkspec.

But what if say, the version of clang uses libc++ by default? Looking *only* at the argument (which should *directly* follow the compiler name) looks kind of fragile and will not catch every case where someone links against libc++.
Suggesting to continue this discussion in #22814 where this commit belongs to.
